speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: We will now hear argument in Illinois against Caballes. General Madigan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, we've held that it's certainly not a -- a full-blown search. It's not a search in the classic sense, but a Terry stop isn't an arrest in -- in the classic sense either. We -- we have said that that is a kind of seizure. Why do -- I think your -- your argument assumes that this for -- for purposes of search analogies that something is either a -- a full-dress search or it's not a search at all. Why isn't there a -- a possibility of - - of a kind of middle ground on searches just as there is on 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 seizures?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Oh, I -- I can -- I can just imagine the problems, but I mean, what -- I think what's -- what the -- what's bothering me about the case is that if we persist in -- in saying that -- that it's -- that it's an either and or question with no question with no possible gradation, then I assume nothing prevents the police from taking the dogs through every municipal garage in the United States and I suppose there's nothing that prevents the police from taking the dogs up to any homeowner's door, ringing the bell, and seeing if the dog gets a sniff of something when the door is opened. We're -- we're opening rather a -- a large vista for -- for dog intrusions, and -- and that's what's -- that's what's bothering me. Why -- why should we -- why should we open that vista if there is a possibility of a -- of a middle ground that would prevent it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Does that imply that your answer is yes to the question? If we say, as you urge, a dog sniff is not a search, then the police are free to parade up and down every street in the country with dogs sniffing car trunks.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But they are used. I mean, we don't have to make it up. From cases we've had here, we know that they're used in places like bus depots to -- to sniff luggage that -- that passengers have carried through on -- on buses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And the republic seems to have survived.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: One could characterize those episodes under the, quote, special needs doctrine. I mean, we are exposed to searches at airports that we would not put up with walking up and down an ordinary street. So the dogs at the terminals one expects nowadays.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No. These aren't sniffs for - - for explosives. These are sniffs for drugs and -- and these -- these are not buses that are coming in from France. They're coming in from one American city to another. And -- and there's no more need in -- in that case than there was in this case. It was just a good -- a good place to find criminals who were carrying unlawful 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 drugs.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I interrupt, General Madigan?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: He was pulled over for speeding at 71 miles an hour in a 65 miles an hour zone on I-80. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Did they know in advance that he was someone to look for? Because I don't imagine you arrest everybody on I-80 that goes 70 miles an hour. I've done it many times myself is why - - (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Inadvertently.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Inadvertently. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You -- you answered one of the earlier questions about the possible intrusiveness of dogs everywhere by saying, well, you don't have a privacy interest in contraband, but that's never true. speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes, but you have a privacy interest in your person and in your place, and that's what we're talking about. So that seems to me that that just doesn't help us.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that's because of the nature of the place being searched not because of the nature of what you're searching for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not necessarily.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So it just can't be that -- so the fact that you don't have a privacy interest in contraband, it doesn't seem to me -- I -- I don't think you need that argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think you should use it. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why -- why do you -- are you sure that Kyllo, you know, the -- the imaging case, would have come out the same way if the only thing -- the only thing -- that the imaging could pick out is not any of the other private activities in the home, but the only thing it could possibly discern is a dead body with a knife through the heart? Are you sure the case would have come out the same way? I'm not at all sure. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, what - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you have any authority for that other than Justice Scalia's speculation about how this - - (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- how his Kyllo case might have been written?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: What about a house and -- and the use of a dog to sniff around a door access or a house just because the police think, you know, it's possible this is somebody growing marijuana in the basement or something? Is that all right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: How do you -- how do you reconcile that with the heat sensor case then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: What if the dogs get a little 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 more sophisticated in the future and can also smell a certain kind of perfume, something like that? Would then the whole analysis change?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: How would you know whether the -- the dog -- I don't think the dog alerts, as I'm alerting, for one reason or another. He just alerts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I just learned this morning that some very well trained dogs that are trained to alert for explosives will also alert for certain kinds of rubber in a tire. They didn't realize that. And I think it's entirely possible that dogs would -- there will be false alerts by -- by dogs because it's triggered by something that -- that is not really anticipated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So you would agree the analysis would be different if there could be an innocent cause of the alert as well as the contraband being the cause of the alert.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or if that happened a large percentage of the time. I mean, surely you'd concede that the search is unreasonable if, for every -- every one time, you -- you make somebody open his bag because the dog actually smells narcotics, 99 times you make somebody open his bag because he has apples in it. I mean, wouldn't that go to the reasonableness of - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, do we -- we don't have the probable cause question before us, do we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So what again in your view is the best distinction from Kyllo?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Like what? I thought it was just heat?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What was -- and what was the second?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, but you would argue that 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the same rationale should apply if, instead of using dogs, you had some sophisticated device that would buzz or ring a bell or something whenever the odor of -- of narcotics was present, wouldn't you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER

Now, but -- but this is not a new technology. This is a dog and -- and they had that ability in 1791 just as they had it today. And the rule that when there's no intrusion, there's no search -- there's no reason to depart from that rule with respect to a dog although there would be with respect to some sophisticated new technology that would enable you to find out all sorts of things.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that didn't go to whether it was a search or seizure. I think it goes to whether it was an unreasonable search or seizure. Don't you think so? That what -- what might be unreasonable with respect to a home would not be unreasonable with respect to a suitcase?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But -- but your -- is -- is it -- I understand it to be your position that there simply is no search here. Period.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, I mean, the Fourth Amendment analysis after Katz doesn't -- doesn't depend on trespass, and -- and you have said up to this point that there is no search. And then you have quite rightly said that we have had as a consideration in our minds analytically whether it's fair to say that what the police were doing involved any compromise of a privacy interest. So I'm assuming -- I'm assuming that the police can at least get to the foundation with a dog and they can certainly walk up to the front door and ring the bell. And if they do that with a dog, for the purpose of letting 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the dog sniff and alert, if there's anything to alert to, is it fair to say that there is no compromise of the privacy interests of the people who own the house?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, we could separate the home from the -- from what happened here and still validate the search here if we held that it was a search, but was a reasonable one since all you find is that the person was carrying contraband. It's the only thing that's disclosed. Whereas, if you -- if you did the same thing with -- with regard to a house, which is a more sacrosanct part of one's privacy, it might be an unreasonable search. We -- we could reach that result if we wanted to, couldn't we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: On the other hand, if it were a drug-selling neighborhood or around a park where drugs are frequently sold, would it be legitimate in your view for the police to take drug-sniffing dogs and walk around the public street where cars are parked around that known drug-selling area and see if they could sniff out some contraband in the cars? Is that okay? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm assuming parked cars. You haven't interrupted anybody. Nobody is in the car, parked on a public street.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So you -- you give no significance to the fact that this dog sniff was in the course of a lawful stop where the citizen's rights had already been curtailed to a significant extent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are there -- are there any manuals for law enforcement officers with respect to the time and place of using dogs, or it's just open season?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I don't mean the training to make the dog alert properly. How the police will use them, when, under what circumstances. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Wray.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Meczyk.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why -- why do you say that? I mean, is -- is anything that I observe a search? I mean, suppose I -- I'm a policeman and -- and I'm looking out 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 for, I don't know, people with a nervous tic because I think that that might be somebody who's about to commit a crime or has committed a crime. Have I searched that person because I -- I observe something external?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is there no difference between an investigation and a search?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No. It seems to me your brief and -- and your statement here both seem to assume that there's a search whenever the police investigate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that's not so. They -- one can investigate without searching.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, but that isn't the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What about a policeman who smells marijuana coming out of a car or a residence. He's 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 walking down the street, public street, and he smells marijuana.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. So once you say that, you realize that there are billions and billions of searches that go on every day that the police don't have to justify at all. They just look around.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay? There are billions of them. So the real question is do they have to give a justification for this. And the argument that they don't is simply that it's not in the person's house. When you go out in a public place, even in your car, you might run into people or animals with sharp noses. And a lot of them can detect marijuana. And you know, maybe it's a Limburger cheese. I don't know. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But people are sniffing things that they don't sniff through windows into your house, but they do get odors in your car on the street. So this is the kind of search. Yes, it's a search, but one that the police don't have to justify.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, it's a specific investigative tool when I put on my glasses to look through a window.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't see why it has to - - why that matters if in fact all -- if you go into a car, a police car, and you have -- drive through the neighborhood and look around, you are using a specific investigative tool, the police car, to look around and find out what's going on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What I'm trying to get to is in my own mind it's not a question of the tools. It's a question of the expectation of privacy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that never - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes, but both Place and 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Edmond, opinions from this Court, said sniffs are not searches.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Do you want us to reverse that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, and Edmond also said it's not a search.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: It was the stop of the cars in that case that caused the result.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Fine. We had a context there where we supported it, but in the process said the sniff, the dog sniff, was not a search.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: So you want us to say 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 something else here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: The context here was a legitimate traffic stop.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: The dog sniff is not a search. What difference does it make?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: This -- the trunk of the car didn't have to be opened here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: The trunk of the vehicle did not have to be opened here. You're talking about a dog 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 sniffing on the exterior of the vehicle that was legitimately stopped for a traffic violation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Suppose a policeman follows me around. He just -- just follows me around, observing with his -- with plain eyes, nothing else. Now, is that a search? Does he need probable cause to do that? Now, he's wasting his time and he's wasting public money and maybe he should get fired for doing it, if he has no reason to follow me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And maybe -- maybe I'd have a harassment action against him if he does it, you know, blatantly. But is that a search?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay. So -- so the mere fact that one is in investigating something doesn't make it a search. What does make it a search?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The fact that you find out 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 something?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You think it would be better if he hadn't been stopped? If -- if they just -- just randomly walked up to somebody who was going through a toll booth and had the dog sniff the car, you think that would be a better case - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- for allowing it than -- than yours?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, they said it's to find out if there's any contraband.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The answer was they are at liberty -- the police are at liberty to use dogs to find contraband. And your -- Illinois I think was very candid with the Court in saying we have taken from your decisions that a dog sniff is not a search. So anything else is a matter of police policy. It had nothing to do with the Fourth Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, does it matter if, for instance, in today's world on Capitol Hill we're concerned about terrorist attacks. What if the dog is trained to alert to explosives? Now, can the police just decide they're going to sniff any car that's parked on Capitol Hill?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes or no, in your view. The purpose is to disclose potential explosives in a parked vehicle. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Wherever it is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I still want to go back to my question because I think you may have an answer to it and I want to focus you - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I want to focus you on the question. I think what you're doing, which is a reasonable thing to do, but it isn't my approach, look to the English definition of search. I say forget that. Let's look to the Fourth Amendment because there are a whole range of searches that don't even fall within the Fourth Amendment in the sense that we don't need a justification. And I take Place as saying that dog sniffs is one of those, whether it does or doesn't use the word English search. So I want to know why it is that this dog search is one of the ones that's a Fourth Amendment search, i.e., 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 one of the ones that requires a justification in terms of what the Fourth Amendment is about, privacy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but you don't respond to one point in Place, if I remember correctly. It must be a legitimate expectation of privacy, and if the only thing the dog can detect is something illegitimate, how can you say there's an invasion of a legitimate expectation in privacy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There was something you said in -- in your brief that I thought was unclear. So may I ask you - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: No, he didn't, but I'm asking you to imagine that he did.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: No. I would like to take this scenario as it is except that when the officer gets out of the car, his dog comes with him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, in this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would it be bad? Would it be bad if that's what he did?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But I'm -- I'm trying to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 understand what you meant in your brief when you said if the dog had been in Gillette's car when Gillette stopped Caballes, the situation would have been different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So then it really makes no difference whether it was Gillette who had the dog in his car or whether the dispatcher called another officer who had the dog.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- is -- is - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay. That's -- that's what I think you should say.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, but that isn't -- I take it you don't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there anything wrong with 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the policeman himself taking a sniff?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's the great Limburger cheese robbery. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He stopped the car and he walks around. Anything wrong with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So plain - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. So -- so what you're saying is -- and this must tie back to reasonable expectation of privacy. All right? Because it's okay for the policeman to do it, and it's okay for dogs to do it in the bus station, and it's okay to use a dog not in the bus station with a car if in fact you actually are going to put him under arrest, although here you had probable cause to do so, I take it. And now you have to draw a pretty fine line. But it's not okay where it's not the bus station, but it is the car and in fact the dog is doing the sniffing -- and there are a lot of dogs around that can sniff -- and you did have probable cause but you 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 didn't say it. And in face of Justice O'Connor's case which said that -- you see. Well, I mean, this is -- this is - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, I'm not saying you couldn't draw that line, but I'm saying it's pretty tough I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I don't know. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm right? Am I -- I mean, that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And you're going to draw the - - well, I don't want you to repeat yourself necessarily.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you had already drawn the line at a different place than Justice Breyer suggested because in response to Justice Scalia, you said if it - - if it were going into the bus terminal just to sniff for narcotics, unlike explosives, it would be an impermissible search.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That would be - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But -- but is -- why -- why don't you simply say, look -- have a very simple line. If they can arrest, they can sniff. If they can't arrest, they can't sniff without individualized suspicion going to drugs or whatever.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But what -- what is the answer to the reasonable expectation to privacy question in that case? Isn't your expectation of privacy identical, whatever it may be, or isn't the reasonable expectation of privacy identical, whatever that may be, without regard to the discretionary decision of the officer to arrest or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But you're saying that the - - the reasonable expectation of privacy depends upon the officer's discretionary judgment whether or not to arrest. Isn't that what you're saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, I think it's worse if -- if you're subjected to it without having committed any violation at all. Every time I travel abroad and come back into the country, customs officers have dogs and - - and they parade the dogs through -- through the baggage terminal. Do -- do I feel offended by that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: This isn't a public safety matter. They're -- they're not smelling for bombs. They're -- they're smelling for contraband. And according to you, that is bad.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay. A bus station is different, though.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Meczyk. General Madigan, you have I think about 3 minutes left.
